column3: For I dare say there was never gentlewoman reviled man in so foul a manner as I have rebuked him; and at all times he gave me goodly and meek answers again.

column2: And as they sat thus talking, there came Sir Gareth in at the gate with an angry countenance, and his sword drawn in his hand, and cried aloud that all the castle might hear it, saying: Thou traitor, Sir Gringamore, deliver me my dwarf again, or by the faith that I owe to the order of knighthood, I shall do thee all the harm that I can.
column3: And as they sat thus talking, there came Sir Gareth in at the gate with an angry countenance, and his sword drawn in his hand, and cried aloud that all the castle might hear it, saying: Thou traitor, Sir Gringamore, deliver me my dwarf again, or by the faith that I owe to the order of knighthood, I shall do thee all the harm that I can.

column2: Then Sir Gringamore looked out at a window and said, Sir Gareth of Orkney, leave thy boasting words, for thou gettest not thy dwarf again.
column3: Then Sir Gringamore looked out at a window and said, Sir Gareth of Orkney, leave thy boasting words, for thou gettest not thy dwarf again.

column2: Thou coward knight, said Sir Gareth, bring him with thee, and come and do battle with me, and win him and take him.
column3: Thou coward knight, said Sir Gareth, bring him with thee, and come and do battle with me, and win him and take him.

column2: So will I do, said Sir Gringamore, an me list, but for all thy great words thou gettest him not.
column3: So will I do, said Sir Gringamore, an me list, but for all thy great words thou gettest him not.

column2: Ah! fair brother, said Dame Lionesse, I would he had his dwarf again, for I would he were not wroth, for now he hath told me all my desire I keep no more of the dwarf.
column3: Ah! fair brother, said Dame Lionesse, I would he had his dwarf again, for I would he were not wroth, for now he hath told me all my desire I keep no more of the dwarf.

column2: And also, brother, he hath done much for me, and delivered me from the Red Knight of the Red Launds, and therefore, brother, I owe him my service afore all knights living.
column3: And also, brother, he hath done much for me, and delivered me from the Red Knight of the Red Launds, and therefore, brother, I owe him my service afore all knights living.

column2: And wit ye well that I love him before all other, and full fain I would speak with him.
column3: And wit ye well that I love him before all other, and full fain I would speak with him.

column2: But in nowise I would that he wist what I were, but that I were another strange lady.
column3: But in nowise I would that he wist what I were, but that I were another strange lady.

column2: Well, said Sir Gringamore, sithen I know now your will, I will obey now unto him.
column3: Well, said Sir Gringamore, sithen I know now your will, I will obey now unto him.

column2: And right therewithal he went down unto Sir Gareth, and said: Sir, I cry you mercy, and all that I have misdone I will amend it at your will.
column3: And right therewithal he went down unto Sir Gareth, and said: Sir, I cry you mercy, and all that I have misdone I will amend it at your will.

column2: And therefore I pray you that ye would alight, and take such cheer as I can make you in this castle.
column3: And therefore I pray you that ye would alight, and take such cheer as I can make you in this castle.

column2: Shall I have my dwarf? said Sir Gareth.
column3: Shall I have my dwarf? said Sir Gareth.

column2: Yea, sir, and all the pleasaunce that I can make you, for as soon as your dwarf told me what ye were and of what blood ye are come, and what noble deeds ye have done in these marches, then I repented of my deeds.
column3: Yea, sir, and all the pleasaunce that I can make you, for as soon as your dwarf told me what ye were and of what blood ye are come, and what noble deeds ye have done in these marches, then I repented of my deeds.

column2: And then Sir Gareth alighted, and there came his dwarf and took his horse.
column3: And then Sir Gareth alighted, and there came his dwarf and took his horse.

column2: O my fellow, said Sir Gareth, I have had many adventures for thy sake.
column3: O my fellow, said Sir Gareth, I have had many adventures for thy sake.

column2: And so Sir Gringamore took him by the hand and led him into the hall where his own wife was.
column3: And so Sir Gringamore took him by the hand and led him into the hall where his own wife was.

column2: CHAPTER XXI.
column3: CHAPTER twenty one.

column2: How Sir Gareth, otherwise called Beaumains, came to the presence of his lady, and how they took acquaintance, and of their love.
column3: How Sir Gareth, otherwise called Beaumains, came to the presence of his lady, and how they took acquaintance, and of their love.

column2: AND then came forth Dame Lionesse arrayed like a princess, and there she made him passing good cheer, and he her again; and they had goodly language and lovely countenance together.
column3: AND then came forth Dame Lionesse arrayed like a princess, and there she made him passing good cheer, and he her again; and they had goodly language and lovely countenance together.

column2: And Sir Gareth thought many times, Jesu, would that the lady of the Castle Perilous were so fair as she was.
column3: And Sir Gareth thought many times, Jesu, would that the lady of the Castle Perilous were so fair as she was.

column2: There were all manner of games and plays, of dancing and singing.
column3: There were all manner of games and plays, of dancing and singing.

column2: And ever the more Sir Gareth beheld that lady, the more he loved her; and so he burned in love that he was past himself in his reason; and forth toward night they yede unto supper, and Sir Gareth might not eat, for his love was so hot that he wist not where he was.
column3: And ever the more Sir Gareth beheld that lady, the more he loved her; and so he burned in love that he was past himself in his reason; and forth toward night they yede unto supper, and Sir Gareth might not eat, for his love was so hot that he wist not where he was.

column2: All these looks espied Sir Gringamore, and then at-after supper he called his sister Dame Lionesse into a chamber, and said: Fair sister, I have well espied your countenance betwixt you and this knight, and I will, sister, that ye wit he is a full noble knight, and if ye can make him to abide here I will do him all the pleasure that I can, for an ye were better than ye are, ye were well bywaryd upon him.
column3: All these looks espied Sir Gringamore, and then at after supper he called his sister Dame Lionesse into a chamber, and said: Fair sister, I have well espied your countenance betwixt you and this knight, and I will, sister, that ye wit he is a full noble knight, and if ye can make him to abide here I will do him all the pleasure that I can, for an ye were better than ye are, ye were well bywaryd upon him.

column2: Fair brother, said Dame Lionesse, I understand well that the knight is good, and come he is of a noble house.
column3: Fair brother, said Dame Lionesse, I understand well that the knight is good, and come he is of a noble house.

column2: Notwithstanding, I will assay him better, howbeit I am most beholden to him of any earthly man; for he hath had great labour for my love, and passed many a dangerous passage.
column3: Notwithstanding, I will assay him better, howbeit I am most beholden to him of any earthly man; for he hath had great labour for my love, and passed many a dangerous passage.

column2: Right so Sir Gringamore went unto Sir Gareth, and said, Sir, make ye good cheer, for ye shall have none other cause, for this lady, my sister, is yours at all times, her worship saved, for wit ye well she loveth you as well as ye do her, and better if better may be.
column3: Right so Sir Gringamore went unto Sir Gareth, and said, Sir, make ye good cheer, for ye shall have none other cause, for this lady, my sister, is yours at all times, her worship saved, for wit ye well she loveth you as well as ye do her, and better if better may be.

column2: An I wist that, said Sir Gareth, there lived not a gladder man than I would be. Upon my worship, said Sir Gringamore, trust unto my promise; and as long as it liketh you ye shall sojourn with me, and this lady shall be with us daily and nightly to make you all the cheer that she can.
column3: An I wist that, said Sir Gareth, there lived not a gladder man than I would be. Upon my worship, said Sir Gringamore, trust unto my promise; and as long as it liketh you ye shall sojourn with me, and this lady shall be with us daily and nightly to make you all the cheer that she can.

column2: I will well, said Sir Gareth, for I have promised to be nigh this country this twelvemonth.
column3: I will well, said Sir Gareth, for I have promised to be nigh this country this twelvemonth.

column2: And well I am sure King Arthur and other noble knights will find me where that I am within this twelvemonth.
column3: And well I am sure King Arthur and other noble knights will find me where that I am within this twelvemonth.

column2: For I shall be sought and found, if that I be alive.
column3: For I shall be sought and found, if that I be alive.

column2: And then the noble knight Sir Gareth went unto the Dame Lionesse, which he then much loved, and kissed her many times, and either made great joy of other.
column3: And then the noble knight Sir Gareth went unto the Dame Lionesse, which he then much loved, and kissed her many times, and either made great joy of other.

column2: And there she promised him her love certainly, to love him and none other the days of her life. Then this lady, Dame Lionesse, by the assent of her brother, told Sir Gareth all the truth what she was, and how she was the same lady that he did battle for, and how she was lady of the Castle Perilous, and there she told him how she caused her brother to take away his dwarf, [*2]for this cause, to know the certainty what was your name, and of what kin ye were come.
